display_title.display_title:
Zaïre – Projet de semences :
            Zaïre - Projet semences

subtopic: Crops and Crop Management Systems,Economic Theory & Research,Agricultural Knowledge and Information Systems,Environmental Economics & Policies

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Completion Report on Zaire
            - Seeds Project aimed to increase food production by
            improving the supply of seeds and cassava cuttings. On
            balance, the project is rated unsatisfactory. Institutional
            objectives were achieved only partially and sustainability
            appears unlikely. Project results were a mixture of success
            and failure. The project's main achievement consisted
            in setting up a seed industry, which was its primary goal.
            It was, however, Government's lack of commitment to
            support this achievement, Combined with the inability of
            seed farms to become self-financing through seed sales, as a
            result of Government interference and over-extension, which
            undermined further progress. Even before the current
            political events, Government failed to provide adequate
            commitment to the success of the project, and internal
            management discipline was slipping. The project in its
            actual design proved to be unsustainable without donor
            financing. The following are the main lessons learned from
            the project: (i) There is a need for more focused and
            simpler projects, commensurate with available management
            capabilities. (ii) Project experience confirms that the
            adequate status and advance of varietal improvement is
            critical for the success of seed multiplication efforts.
            (iii) The performance of the Borrower illustrates the need
            to apply credit conditionality more explicitly and
            consistently. (iv) Experience with project supervision
            suggests that more resources for supervision should be made
            available for critical projects of this kind in country
            circumstances which are complex, such as Zaire. (v) Adoption
            of a satisfactory legal framework for the seeds supply
            sub-sector should be a condition for any future Bank support
            to the seed industry.
